text:
S-X2
148. Anderson, (Mrs. James I.)
PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

(Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask., where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.)

Name: Mrs. J. ANDERSON
Address: GREGG, B.R.D.
Birthplace: ONTARIO

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1905
Where did you set up housekeeping? South of Cypress
Where had you been living before that? With an American farmer
For how many people did you prepare meals? 6-7
How far was it to your nearest store? 4 or 5 mile
How often could a visit be made to the store? about three months
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
Sugar, rolled oats, flour (dried), vanilla, cornstarch, lard, butter, flour

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Royal Household and Quaker
In what quantities did you buy it? 100 lb. usually
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? about $3.50
How much did you use graham flour? not at all
Whole wheat flour?
Was flour milled locally? Some. How far away? 13 mile. What year? 1912
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? 75¢
What other grain products did you use?
Cornmeal? Sometimes Whole Wheat? Farina?
Other?
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Sometimes
How did you grind it? In the chopper, put it through three times
1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1865

Where had you been living before that? North Dakota

For how many people did you prepare meals? 4

How far was it to your nearest store? About 20 miles

How often could a visit be made to the store? About twice a month

What grocers did you usually buy in those earliest years?

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Royal Canadian

In what quantities did you buy it? 100 lb. annually

What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? About $5.00

How much did you use graham flour? Not at all

Whole wheat flour?

Was flour milled locally? Yes

What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? $5.00

What other grain products did you use?

Grits?

Other?

Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes

How did you grind it? In the chopper put through three times
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 100 lb.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? about $8.00

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? (not visible)

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 10 oz. and 6 oz.

At what price? M.E. $2.50

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? (not visible)

Butter? (not visible) Eggs? kept a few hens.

What was the price of butter? 25¢-9¢

Did you pack eggs for winter? sometimes

Did you make butter? yes

Did you make cheese? sometimes

What kind of cheese? Dutch cheese and regular cheese sometimes

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? beef & pork

How did you get fresh meat? killed it

How often did you get fresh meat? just in the winter

How did you preserve meat? canned it in salers and cured it

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? no

If so what year was it organized?

Did you use game? when we could get it

What kinds? ducks, chickens and rabbits

For how long? in the fall and winter

What part did fish play in the family diet? very little if a puddler went through we got some fresh

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned?

Kinds? canned salmon, sardines & herring (seldom)

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? _______ lb.

What was the price of a ten pound sack of white sugar? _______ cts.

What kind of flour did you use? _______

What size of tin of syrup did you buy? _______

At what price? _______

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

Butter? _______

Did you make butter? _______

What kind of cheese? _______

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? _______

How did you get fresh meat? _______

How often did you get fresh meat? _______

How did you preserve meat? _______

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? _______

If so, what year was it organized? _______

Did you use game? _______

For how long? _______

What part did fish play in the family diet? _______

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? _______

Finds? _______
6. BEVERAGES

What kind of tea did you buy? Lifton & Eaton's
At what price? $1.75

What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground)
Price? $2.00

What other beverages were used?

7. VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping? $3.00

Could you get potatoes at the store? Yes

If not, where from? Idaho

What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of:
Potatoes 1904
Cabbage 1904
Carrots 1904
Onions 1904
Turnips 1904
Beets 1904

In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? 10 lbs.

How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? By the box

What weight? 25 lbs.

How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? In boxes

What was the price of prunes? $3.00

What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currants or others)

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? Yes

peas? Yes
corn? Yes
beans? Yes
Saskatoons? No
other foods?

What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? 1911

What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? 1911

What year did you first preserve meat by canning? 1910

Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? Yes

To what extent? About 100 qts. of fruit and 50 qts. of meat

Did you make your own vinegar? Yes, but I made my own soap

What kind of corn did you buy? _______ _______
What other vegetables were used? _______ _______

10. BAKING

What type of yeast did you use? Royal Yeast cake

Did you make yeast for your own use? Sometimes

Using starter? Sometimes

Using hops? Yes

Salt rising? No

Did you buy baking powder? Yes

Baking soda? Yes

Cream of tartar? Rarely

Did you make your own baking powder? No

Did you make yeast for your own use? Using starter?

Using hops? Yes

Did you buy baking powder? Yes

Cream of tartar? No

Did you make your own baking powder?

12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout) first three months slough then we dug a well.

How far was this water from your home? about three rods.

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) pail.

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

We had to chase the cattle about ¼ of a mile to water now we have a dugout about 200 yds away. We sometimes had to draw water with a tank and put in the well in the fall but late years the same well provides plenty. It is about 20 ft deep and cribbed up.
12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout)

How far was this water from your home?

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank, hail)

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

We had to chase the cattle about 3/4 of a mile to within mow, we have a dugout about 200 yds away. We sometimes had to draw water with a hand and foot in the well in the fall, but late years the same well provided plenty of water about 200 yds and could be used.

12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout) first three months slough then we dug a well.

How far was this water from your home? about three rods.

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) pail.

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

We had to chase the cattle about ¼ of a mile to water now we have a dugout about 200 yds away. We sometimes had to draw water with a tank and put in the well in the fall but late years the same well provides plenty. It is about 20 ft deep and cribbed up.
12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, cistern, dugout)

How far was this water from your home?

How was it brought to the house? (pail, barrel, tank)

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started homesteading, giving dates where possible.

We had to choose the cattle about 3/4 of a mile to north where we have a dugout about 200 ft away. We sometimes had to draw water with a hand pump. The well in the field, but late August the same well provided plenty of water for the crops and cattle.
13. SOAP

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own?  
If you made your own, did you use lye?  
What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer handle?

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days?  
Where did you get your fuel?  
Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

We have used coal some for about 30 years and some have oil burners the last four years.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates)  
Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates)

By whom was your first cook stove made?  
What year was it purchased?  
Price?  
What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade)  
For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other)  
When did you first see enamel ware?  
Aluminum?
14. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates)

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates)

By whom was your first cook stove made?

What year was it purchased?

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tins, homemade)

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other)

When did you first see enamel ware? (about 1910) Thank

Aluminum?
16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

It used to be all paper and cardboard or to plastic and cellophane now. We got far more wooden boxes as biscuits and apples etc were put up that way.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast: Rolled oats porridge, coffee, bread & butter
Dinner: Potatoes, vegetables & meat, dessert (not sugar)
Supper: Potatoes, meat, Bread & butter, fruit & milk

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? .......

Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at the time.

We always managed some sort of a treat for Christmas as a rule. A plum pudding and roast of some sort. I think it was about 1912 before we had a real dinner then about 12 present a neighbor had the same size family and same ages 6 - 8 - 10 & 12 years.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

No. But I was often glad when I could get enough vegetables from my garden to make a milk soup, a few onions, potatoes & carrots and once when we were out of flour my husband walked 24 mile and borrowed a team and waggon and brought home a sack of flour and a few other things.
17. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada?

Give the month.

We always managed some sort of food at Christmas as a rule. In 1912 after we had a nice dinner then about 1/2 percent a neighbor had the same size family and same ages 6-8-10 or 12 years old.

18. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

No. But I was often glad when I could get enough vegetables from my garden to make a milk soup a few times a month and once a year my husband walked 2½ mile until borrowed a team and wagon and brought home a sack of flour and a few other things.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

It was very different when we started to get a meal everything had to be prepared now we can go in our cellar and find enough for a meal any day if we have to.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

1942 we started buying bread and creamery butter.
1940 " " " Orange
1945 " " " Greens
about that time more canned foods
1930 corn flakes & puffed wheat etc.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

My husband once went to Maclean to purchase groceries among them colo oil and flour. On his way home he tied up the horses (bronks) and went in a house to see about a midwife. And found when he came out the horses had broken loose and gone. He walked home eleven mile and hunted three days for the team and found them looking very quaint. The colo oil was spilled in the flour. We tried to use it, but it created too much gas, so it was used for making paste etc.

That was 1907
It was very difficult to get a meal every day without purchasing new food. We had to find enough for a meal every day if we had to.

1942 we started buying bread and canned fruits.

1945 ground about that time we bought canned foods.

1950 corn flakes so filled about 6 oz.

Dry husband and wife went to Cheyenne to purchase.

They found the flour (chocolate) and went in a hurry to see about a maid wife. And found when he came out the house had broken loose and gone.

He walked home eleven mile and hunted three days for the team and found them looking very giant. The cattle oil was spilled in the floor.

We tried to use it, but it created too much gum.

So it was used for making paste etc.

That was 1907.
Oxford

No. 613 S
